Mathematical Fallacy

Sometimes, doing mathematics can lead to certain kinds of mistaken proof, that is proofs which look correct but actually contain an error in either logic or calculation. These are illustrations of mathematical fallacy. There is a difference between a mathematical fallacy and a simple mistake. A mathematical fallacy is so called because it contains some element of concealment or deception in the presentation of the proof. For example, this may be a division by zero which is hidden simply by algebraic notation. In the rest of this section we will examine some common mathematical fallacies.
